photo.title: Uncaring 5_Pierre

description._content: The city controls the pigeon by building pigeon houses. I dont get it. In which place is this useful for the city.

photo.tags: paris male publicspace cleanliness uncaring age26

photo.title: Uncaring 4_Pierre

description._content: The subway is disgusting. There is pee and littering everywhere. I dont find this in the other cities. I dont why it is so in Paris. But, everywhere Ive lived, Boston and Barcelona, the subway is cleaner.

photo.tags: paris male publicspace hygiene cleanliness uncaring age26

photo.title: Uncaring 3_Pierre

description._content: Maybe, it is a bit clich, but nobody talks on the subway. I dont think there is anything done by the RATP or the city about that. RATP controls the musicians inside the subway. They do interviews of musicians. But there are very few candidates (slots) and there are plenty of musicians. They are not allowed to play inside the carriages.

photo.tags: paris male mobility socialinteraction uncaring age26

photo.title: Uncaring 2_Pierre

description._content: When I was younger, I had my metro card for an year, and this is the first year when I used the monthly transportation card. When you want to recharge your card there is an hour line to do it, every time. Everybody (wants to recharge) at the same period of the month, at the end of the month or the start of the month, and it is a problem.

photo.tags: paris male publictransit metro service mobility uncaring age26

photo.title: Uncaring 1_Pierre

description._content:
Empty Velieb station, Rue Cualiancourt
Every morning I walk up, and I want to use the shared biking system Velieb, and there is never a bike. Its maybe because I dont live in the center, and Montmatre is a (at the top of the) hill and there is never a bike near my place. If there is one bike, you can be very sure that it doesnt work. I have plenty of apps that tell me where the bikes are and I walk there only to find the bikes not working. (unclear)

photo.tags: paris male bike publictransit mobility uncaring age26 sharingeconomy velieb

photo.title: Caring 6_Pierre

description._content: I love the fact that there is always something going on. If I want to do something, there is something. There are different possibilities.

photo.tags: paris male publicspace culture diversity caring age26

photo.title: Caring 5_Pierre

description._content:
I love the fact that in Paris you can buy from one shop to another, they can be on the same side of the street. Vegetable like it was grown, and fresh. It makes
people get to know Paris, you get to find the right address.

photo.tags: food paris male local caring wellbeing helth age26

photo.title: Caring 4_Pierre

description._content: We are really proud of our food, our restaurant, our sightseeing. Lot of Parisian go to tour Eiffel at least once a year. In lot of countries youve been people dont really follow the culture you believe them to. In Paris, the city supports people to have a Parisian life. For the food there are little funds for restaurants or grocery stores, who follow Parisian culture. They have help from the city and from the region, so they can continue to have good meat or good bread.

photo.tags: food paris male culture identity local caring age26

photo.title: Caring 3_Pierre

description._content: All my furniture comes from the street. That is maybe because in the center of Paris there are lot of young and old people, and families tend to go to suburb. There is a turnaround n the city when there is a lot of great furniture on the street. And you get a lot of great furniture on the streets. If you have something you can call the city, you dont have the right to put anything on the streets by yourself. From the city there is an effort to regulate that, it is called (unclear), you get to call a number and the truck from a city pick-up the furniture, and goes to the association of poor. Its great. The furniture stays for only 10 minutes before people take it.

photo.tags: street paris male publicspace furniture caring age26

photo.title: Caring 2_Pierre

description._content: This is an interesting one I like how the city cares about not caring. There is a beautiful alley there is paint, and its really neat. You can expect that every little shop will be like a gift shop or something Parisian, but its not. There are lot of paysages in the city, there are lot of pretty ones. This is one of my favorite. Its good because it is a melting pot, inside a very Parisian structure. There dont seem to be any rules to make this a touristic place. No rules that say that there has to be a caf or a restaurant here.

photo.tags: paris male publicspace culture caring age26 relationshiptostate

photo.title: Caring 1_Pierre

description._content:
I like the fact that anytime of the year you can sit outside. It is very Parisian, but I dont get why its not everywhereThere is a saying in French the small theatre from the street. I like it. It happens in the metro, it happens
everywhere, you cant just be outside and observe the life around.

photo.tags: street paris male publicspace culture caring age26

description._content:
#glasgow #caring #mobility #bike #hack

These little hacks are just down from GSA and they solve the problem for cyclists of how to use this footbridge. Such a small intervention makes such a big difference and it shows thought, it is perhaps a little late.

#glasgow #caring #publicspaces #wellbeing 


This picture is of one Glasgows parks. Im a big fan of how many and how big the parks in
Glasgow are. Its nice that they havent been sold off to developers and give a place for people to
escape from the city. I used to walk through Kelvingrove Park into Uni every day and it was the
best parts of my day, totally letting me unwind and chill out.

#glasgow #caring #publicspaces #culture


This image shows Buchanan St, the main shopping thoroughfare in Glasgow. What I like about this
is firstly that its been pedestrianised and covered with Christmas lights which just makes it a better atmosphere for everyone. Secondly, its probably the most thriving public space in Glasgow which gives it a cool energy and theres always something happening here.

#glasgow #caring #publicspaces #culture

This image is of Wellington outside the GoMA. The cone used to be removed after it was put up
there, but whenever they did it would be replaced within 24 hours. Eventually the council said let it be, and now its embraced by the council. Its not often a city gets to show a sense of humour, but Glasgow has done it here and also with Nelson Mandela Place.

photo.title: photo2 2_Gunc

description._content: This is a huge park surrounded by the fences. But, Turkish people just want to interact and sit here. But, the city makes fences around them, so that it looks beautiful, but people cant really use it.

photo.tags: park male publicspace fences istanbul uncaring age27

photo.title: photo 44_Gunc

description._content: This is like a park where they put transmitter for cellphones, which is not good for your health. I dont know if it is still, but there is a perception so people would not really use this space. But, they dont really care, because it is good for transmission.

description._content: They put this huge billboard, a digital billboard. But, people adapted it you know, putting a place to sit. The city didnt care when they were putting this, but people start caring about the space.

description._content: This is like the signs and the LEDs for me it is very distracting from a design perspective.

description._content: It is a huge hotel, normally the FIR around here is very low. But, with bribing and illegal ways they built this. This is happening everywhere, and makes you wonder who does the city really care for?

description._content: This is not the care part. This is one of the best kind of places with the view. But, blocking this view there is a car park.

description._content: This is for animals. There are places where people put food for stray dogs and cats.

description._content: This is the Dolmus system. Minibuses, is an obvious example of how people informally created a transportation for each other. For me its the caring for each other.

photo.title: 3_Gunc

description._content: This is the place where the musicians, street musicians normally play. The design can be debatable, but the city government made this to cover them. So that they continue playing music there.

photo.title: IMG_9149_Yoltar

description._content:
Even though I hate places where there is no any tree or some green areas, this scene make me relaxed
because It means there is no traffic so I can go home on the time. And as you can see in the other
pictures, I hate slops and little ways so its another reason why it makes me relaxed.

photo.tags: female publictransit traffic istanbul caring mobility age22

photo.title: IMG_9142_Yoltar

description._content:
It's another picture from my road to the university. Basically I hate this road. But its the most
comfortable one to go and back to me. Thanks God, still I did not break my any legs until now.

photo.tags: female publictransit istanbul infrastructure roads mobility uncaring age22

description._content:
This picture was taken in my family flat. This neighborhood is newly populated comparing to the other
parts of the Istanbul, this is why it is one of the few places which still you can survive in the cold very
easily. You can enjoy the weather in winter, rather then suffering from cold.

photo.title: IMG_9140_Yoltar

description._content:
This is the road I take every single day I go to my university. As you can see its disgusting way,
especially if it is raining, you utterly be miserable because water will be soaked into your clothes.

photo.tags: female publictransit istanbul infrastructure roads mobility uncaring age22

description._content:
Actually this photo represents two different things on my mind. Sometimes I feel really lucky to live in
this city when Im sitting here, but if it smells everything is going to change in my mind and I feel
really unlucky.

photo.title: IMG_8363_Yoltar

description._content:
The cutest dog ever! During the night I don't feel comfortable on the way when I'm going home, but
this dog always follow me and it makes me feel more comfortable. Having him as a is my friend during
the way is very nice.

photo.tags: female publicspace istanbul safety caring age22

This is from a coffee house, I love this place because whenever I go to this place I feel happy. With its
people and location, I feel like it is just perfect for me.

description._content:
It's another picture to show my suffering from Istanbul. The worst thing is that this place in the center
of Istanbul, -so called- a metropolis city. Has a lot of hard dirt on the floor, which makes walking much
harder than it is in a rainy weather.

photo.tags: female publicspace istanbul infrastructure roads mobility uncaring age22

photo.title: IMG_9235_Yoltar

description._content:
Maybe I should feel lucky because if there is rain we always have little lakes in the center of Istanbul,
so I should not complain but mostly I'm not well equipment so, when I see this lakes I want to cry.

photo.title: db-uncaring04

description._content:
Istanbul is one of the most crowded city in world. Because of this the public
transportations in Istanbul is full. Sometimes you don't even have enough space to enter
in bus, which may cause a delay to the place you want to arrive.

photo.tags: female publictransit istanbul infrastructure caring crowded age20 mobilty uncaring

photo.title: db-uncaring03

description._content:
There is water pound in the middle of Istanbul almost everyday i am passing from this
bridge in order to go to university. The water is extremely dirty and it gives out a heavy
smell, which cause air pollution as well. This is another thing, which disturbs me in
Istanbul.

photo.tags: female publicspace istanbul pollution sanitation age20 uncaring

photo.title: db-uncaring02

description._content:
In the most touristic places such as Taksim there neglected buildings, which gives a very
bad view it sullies the name of Istanbul.

photo.tags: history architecture female publicspace neglect istanbul maintenance age20 uncaring

photo.title: db-caring05

description._content:
Mosques in Istanbul I think the most precious things in Istanbul. Specially when they call
you to pray for 5 times a day. But I took Eyp Sultan Mosque specially because it is a
very historic and a huge mosque.

photo.tags: history female publicspace religion istanbul mosque identity caring age20

photo.title: db-caring04

description._content: I wanted to take the photograph of the biggest theme park in Istanbul because this is the place where I see all kind of people happy and enjoying the moment. Being happy with thousands of people at the same time makes me feel better than being in any other place.

photo.tags: female publicspace istanbul caring age20 socialinteraction recreationalspaces

photo.title: db-caring03

description._content:
Istanbul is the only city where you can pass from Europe to Asia without a passport or
any other control. You can travel with a ferry-boat from one continent to the other while
you drink your tea and the same time watch the beautiful view of the Bosphorus.

photo.tags: female boats publictransit character istanbul caring mobility cityviews age20

description._content: I took this image because this is the place where I am away from the crowded and noisy parts of my city.

photo.title: uncaring5_Sinirlioglu

description._content:
A pedestrian underpass in Karaky, a very important centre near the Golden Horn. Although this
place is very carinng for me during the day, when people can buy stuff before work or home, at nights,
with all of the shops closed, it is again a dark, empty place that makes me feel insecure.

photo.tags: female publicspace istanbul safety age29 uncaring

photo.title: uncaring4_Sinirlioglu

description._content:
This is an important metro line of the Asian side, connecting to the European side by Marmaray
(metro line that goes through the Bosphorous) and the pier. However this line goes right under a
highway. Metros are for pedestrians. This exit of the metro, being the closest one to a residential area,
is still an unsecure, dark place that doesn't feel like in a city.

photo.tags: female publictransit istanbul infrastructure age29 mobility accessibility uncaring

photo.title: uncaring3_Sinirlioglu

description._content:
A road+pedestrian way under a highway. These places are again unsecure "non-places" that are
totally erased from the urban fabric.

photo.tags: female publicspace highway publictransit istanbul infrastructure roads age29 mobility uncaring

photo.title: uncaring2_Sinirlioglu

description._content:
Fikirtepe, an urban transformation area i passed by on the bus. It was an old slum area in the city and now is a very valuable are in the means of real estate. Urban transformation lost all the great
neighbourhood life of the area and will be filled with highrise gated communities. I feel lost now in these urban transformation areas that I used to know well. Now, the city is demolishing my urban
memory and I start to feel like an outsider in these places.

photo.tags: female istanbul housing age29 slums uncaring urbanmemory urbantransformation informalcommunities

photo.title: uncaring1_Sinirlioglu

description._content:
.Where I start my daily routine, living in a gated community. The roads between the fastly emerging
gated communities make me feel insecure and unhappy.

photo.tags: female publicspace istanbul housing suburbs age29 gatedcommunity uncaring

photo.title: Hale-caring5_Sinirlioglu

description._content:
A large coast full of parks and recreational areas. Most parts of the coasts of this city are filled with
private properties. Therefore, this specific coast line is a great and caring area for both human and
animal citizens of the city. The photo is again important for me because of its opportunities for the
street animals, which are symbols of Istanbul.

photo.tags: female publicspace parks istanbul caring age29 dogwalking

photo.title: Hale-caring4_Sinirlioglu

description._content:
A public toilet in Gezi Park, which has been a symbol of public place and park in Istanbul since June
2013. Public toilets around public spaces are rarely found in this city, so places with them make me
feel more cared.

photo.tags: female publicspace istanbul infrastructure caring age29 publictoilets amenities

photo.title: Hale-caring1_Sinirlioglu

description._content:
Bicycle parks, especially at transfer points in the public transportation. Bicycles are used rarely in
Istanbul in the everyday life. Moreover, it is hard to use bicycles everywhere because of the steep
streets, and sloped topography. Therefore it is a caring fact to have enough bicycle parks at points of
public transportation stations.

photo.tags: bike female parking istanbul caring publictransport age29 mobility

photo.title: Hale-caring_Sinirlioglu

description._content:
Around public spaces, public transportation routes and street points of shelter make me feel cared.
This photo is important because the entrance roof of the pier creates both a point of gathering,
sheltering and spending time in the daily life for the citizens. And the photo shows that the city can be
caring for all its citizens in this way, both humans and street animals, which are un-ignorable citizens
of Istanbul.

photo.tags: street female publicspace istanbul safety caring shelter age29

description._content: Walking to work on Memorial Drive, this is a sidewalk that is basically no one has taken responsibility for it, the office building next to it hasnt taken responsibility for it. and commuters use this sidewalk  all the tie. There is no bike lane so what happens often is that pedestrians are sharing the sidewalk with cyclists and its hard because its narrow. The leaves are an ex of how narrow it can get, but when it snows its even worse, theres basically a mouse trail in the center that you have to walk through and you have a cyclist behind you and hop over on the snow and let them past. Its a frustrating part of my winter when I have to take this route I avoid it at all costs because its sidewalk but then its not. It basically doesnt exist if the weathers bad.

photo.title: Uncaring 5

description._content: This is a bus stop and its  I know a lot dont have any kind of shelter  this happens to beat Fenway station and it often fills up beyond that. This day it was freezing, it was one of the first really cold days of the winter  20 degrees  -and theres no. theres not more than one. By the time the bus gets there, there are nearly 20 people and not everyone has coverage, and some are standing in the rain or cold, and for a bus stop thats at a main train station they should have more adequate coverage and shelter. You could be waiting out there in the cold and the wet with nothing to over you if this little tiny pocket is full.

photo.tags: bus boston female publictransit mobility uncaring

description._content: This is next to Fenway station, so this is where I stand to take the bus every day and it just looks like a really really sad image and just a nice little pocket of Boston where you can see how people really dont care sometimes. Its on a slope so I imagine thats why it has more trash than other parts I travel by because its hard to travel by, its overgrown by all these dead plants, and then theres this structure that weve put there. Its one of those corners that nobody takes responsibility for. But the building mgmt. probably also doesnt want to take ownership of it, but its there and its a mess

This goes up  I look a closeup shot  its almost every other step, its at Reservoir station and theyre all sunken in and its really dangerous and the city has not repaired it, this is a pretty busy station, and I dont know why it hasnt been fixed yet, I never submitted a report myself, and I figured theyd take care of it, every other step is sunken in, it catches you by surprise and its just kind of annoying thing to have to deal with on a day to day basis.

This is something Ive noticed a lot, more than than any other biz, Dunkin Donuts items are everywhere. People throw their cups on the street and anyways, these are the munchkins, someone had just thrown it, its very strange because I dont know if they were angry. It really gets under my skin every time I see a DD thing I just curse them. Im like why are they making all these things why dont they educate their customers about not littering Its kinda crazy the ratio of other biz to DD that I see about the city

Those are all over Boston, this one is near my house in Newton but we do have a lake near us that is a public rec lake. But these you can find on the Boston side of the Charles and around Cambridge or along the seaport in the north end, youll see these little placards and its just a reminder that were in a city but were surrounded by water and this is something to be mindful of and I think its not going to stop anyone, its not an official thing but its nice that the city put in the money to install these things to serve as reminder to people.

photo.title: Caring 5

description._content: Theres priority seating, youre probably not going to be arrested for not giving up your seat, but regularly on the T - and I take the D line on the Green Line - but people are always giving up their seats to people who need it more. Its one of those nice things when you see how considerate people ae, which doesnt happen often on the T, I find.

photo.tags: boston female publictransit caring mobility accessibility

photo.title: Caring 4

description._content: Yeah that was a service dog n the T. A lot of my photos are from the T btw and its just funny how everyones face  I felt self conscious. Everyone loves it when. It happens often that people bring service dogs on the T, and everyone makes space for them and is super respectful of the owner and the dogs personal space. Also that people have the freedom to go throughout the city

photo.tags: boston female publictransit caring mobility accesibility

description._content: This was downtown Boston near Copley area and this is just  by the Lenox hotel  and the hotel must have paid for it. Its this idea of environmentally friendly way and making it easy for people who are using electric cards to park and charge them throughout the city. I havent seen one walking around Boston.

Along the route where I do my grocery shopping, I dont live near grocery stories and there are just these random metal cut-outs of birds on the street and its just a nice little pick me up. Its artwork, I dont know who decided to put there or if it has some Boston or literary meaning but theyre cute. Theyre strewn all along that intersection, on that other theres a group of finches and its just a nice thing to see every day. Its nice when not everything is utilitarian, to have these little touches of whimsy is sort of a mood booster for people.

So I took this on the morning  I commute and I have to cross this bridge to get to my work building, this is on Memorial Drive in Cambridge. Runners often run by the Charles River and use the water fountain, I believe its a BU building and so they pay for it to be there. Its the only public water fountain Ive seen like that around campus and people use it a lot and it seems like something that should be part of the way that we see park benches, like a water fountain seems like a really obvious public thing that everyone uses.

Stepping back from the issue at hand, we can just talk about it as a protest. [Note: G didnt feel comfortable talking about the main issue]

G: One thing I found very interesting and that I had a pretty strange but visceral response to was the fact that we walked down this highway ramp, and right here is the municipal prison. We were chanting to the prisoners who were coming to the windows of their room and were making noise by mainly tapping on the window because that was the only way they could communicate with us. But they were taking part in the protest, taking part in the chanting, taking part of being a community around the issue. I had never interacted with people who were in prison before

Its so private and its so public at the same time. Its like a public announcement of something that is so full of emotion for this one person that they had to, or whoever decided to write it in chalk on a construction site, that they had to announce it to the world.

What I like about this photo is that right there is the state house dome. I loved that the state house dome, which is such a big and imposing and has so much presence, and here it is turned as cute and as small as the rest of the hill There is an accessibility of it. Stripping Beacon Hill of its meaning as a very bourgeois neighborhood, I do like the way you can just look at the self contained thing right there, that has so much presence and you can just take it in in one moment.

Going back to the relationship between you and the city and the city embracing you, and you embracing the city, you can really wrap yourself around this Beacon Hill much more than when you are sitting in the park and the State House is this towering thing above you.

Someone built a bookshelf into the pillar and put all of these trophies onto them. They are what a kid would get in various sports competitions in middle school, and they have various names I saw someone else walk by and take a picture of it after me, so that was kind of funny, and thats probably the way in which people interact with this by taking pictures. I loved that it immediately creates a relationship between you and the person who came and put it there because trophies are such a personal accomplishment. They are about one individual who has done something and they are showing off how amazing they are as an individual. They are very selfish, and they are very personal. Its interesting to think there is one person who is behind these trophies and they have become public. But if I say public art, I feel like I take away from it because I put it in this category of things that have been done to make you think, and I really dont know thats why this was put up. Definitely to make you think, but not in kind of a hipster waythere is something really authentic about the weirdness of finding this there.

What I was trying to capture was this extraordinary sense of space when you are in the North End and youre near the water, and you look towards the center of town and you have density you have downtown, but downtown is this oppressing, lifeless Not just Downtown Crossing, but the whole Financial District just a few blocks South from there is just miserably empty the second work has gotten out. So you have this classic urban [space] but I feel like there is something human about being able to take a step back and look onto it without having to be in the middle of it. In New York, you dont have that it is an island, but you look at Manhattan and there is a wall. There is Manhattan, and then there is not. 

You are not in the center of the city, but you arent separate from it. I feel like the city is giving you your space. Im not a big personal space person, I feel like that is very antisocial, but I still appreciate what the city is doing when you are on the other side of the greenway.
Some parts of the city do not have good sanitary practices. North End trash is routinely thrown on the sidewalk exposing it to rats and vermin carrying diseases.
New condos are being built everywhere and cost too much for the middle class.
Boston does not take care of the roads very well and it is extremely annoying.
The apartments are old and falling apart, with no strict regulations in place.
Boston seems to be expanding its parks in many areas, improving the quality of life for the citizens.
SOWA is a great example of Boston's active participation in selling local products.
This is evidence of the city's growing awareness of the importance of green energy and incentivizing it with free charging stations.
This shows that the city can arrange big events for the citizens, so that they can be outside and enjoying the weather and eachother.
It shows the city's willingness to be avant garde with its architecture, blending modern styles among the historic environment.

The homeless population really detracts from the culture of Cambridge and Boston. I wouldn't take a photo of someone without their consent, but here is an alley which makes the area smell strongly like urine every day.)
Moving vans. It's very difficult to move in with the narrow streets of Cambridge. Also, surprise moving van permits can have your car towed. No fun.
Landscapers are allowed to wake everyone up early in the morning with leaf blowers
There's a lack of bike parking places throughout the city
Crowded public transportation. Things can get a bit packed when commuting on public transportation during rush hour
Festive city and commercial decorations around holidays and different seasons
This nice public graffiti wall is a nice way to showcase public art and creativity
Streets are swept every month for us residents
Many streets in Cambridge are dedicated to residential parking. It goes a long way when you need to park your car as a resident!
Trash and recycling is encouraged and picked up weekly.

photo.title: UN_5

description._content: Finally, this is a photo of the street I live on.  It is a residential neighborhood, but I feel it is not well-lit.  With the winter months bringing less light every day, it would be nice to have a bit more light on the sidewalks.  I know that I live in a safe area, but I can't help but think I would feel a bit more safe on my walk home if there was more light.

photo.tags: boston female safety sidewalk utilities uncaring

description._content: This is a photo of a building near my office that has remained in this state of disrepair for YEARS.  It's windows are boarded up and there is little foot traffic due to the lack of activity.  This not only prevents the rest of the street from improving its status from a not-very-nice area to one that is lively and exciting, but it has also led to thefts in the area.  (my co-worker's car was broken into in broad daylight!)

Again, public transportation can be improved upon.  You may not be able to tell from this photo, but this is a bus stop on Massachusetts Avenue.  There are two benches for seating, but there is no shelter from rain/snow/wind.  It is inconvenient and unwelcoming to have to wait for the bus exposed to the elements and dodging those trying to get by on the sidewalk.

I understand that seating in public areas is to be desired, but I feel that an over-abundance of seating in large public areas (like Central Square-pictured here) only creates opportunity for mischief.  I pass through this area every day and often see people sleeping on the benches, people begging for money, and people who look like they are partaking in not-so-legal transactions.  I'm not sure what the solution is here, but this area in particular is known as being a bit unsafe.

A common sight for me to see are extremely overcrowded buses, which leads to a larger issue of scheduling and the frequency of buses.  After using public transportation for over 2 years here in Boston, I have noticed that the buses seem to come much too infrequently, which is only a result of improper scheduling.  I have watched 4 buses pass me in the opposite direction that I need, while I've had to wait over 20 minutes for one to stop at my stop.  This is because the buses do not get released incrementally, but instead all at once.  This causes extremely overcrowded and extremely empty buses, rather than a more even distribution of passengers.  All-in-all, I feel it is a system that needs to be improved on, ESPECIALLY in the winter months when I personally have waited over 45 minutes in single-digit temperatures for a bus to come.

This is 'Graffiti Alley' near Central Square.  I think this is such a great spot because it takes what is commonly looked at as an eyesore or an act of disobedience and provides an outlet for artists to express their creativity.  Because this area is open to the public to graffiti, it has reduced the amount of unwanted graffiti in the surrounding area (from what I've seen at least).

H-Mart is the (relatively) new Asian supermarket that opened a few months ago in Central Square.  I love that the city is made of so many different cultures that are accessible and easy to explore.  I've gone in to H-Mart and seen fruits and vegetables that are completely new to me and I thoroughly enjoy being able to expose myself to many different foods, drinks, styles of dance, styles of music, etc. so close to home.

Again, at South Station, a photo of the food court shows how many options are in place for those who travel through large transit hubs like this one.  It is always hectic when traveling, whether it is every day or for a special trip, so it is comforting to be able to rely on the facilities at your destination for food and drink options.

This shows the bike storage area at South Station.  I think this is IMMENSELY caring for the city to provide!  Biking, walking and taking public transit can help improve the traffic problems the city has as well as our carbon footprint.  I love seeing free bike storage and encouraging people to get out and exercise more or use a more 'green' mode of transportation.

This photo shows part of the beautiful city skyline in downtown Boston.  I love living in a city where there is a mix of old and new and where the architecture is interesting and exciting.  I like discovering new things every time I walk around a new part of town.

description._content: #glasgow #uncaring #infrastructure
#glasgow #uncaring #cleanliness #safety
#glasgow #uncaring #cleanliness
#glasgow #uncaring #infrastructure #mobility
#glasgow #uncaring #infrastructure #cleanliness
the commodification of everything (EVERYTHING has a price in NYC, even this bathroom), a bathroom stall on the sidewalk near Prospect Park that costs 25 cents for entry

the general mess / noise / environmental pollution / noise pollution / light pollution in this city (ok, I'm really grateful for construction workers and what they accomplish, but sometimes it feels like EVERYTHING is being blown up and dug up)
gentrification and disregard for history/community, a gym recently built inside an old, beautiful church
police brutality
crowdedness and the people (namely straight white boys) with no regard for how much space they take up
amazing library system / access to books
access to excellent food and agriculture
excellent parks and open spaces
accessible, reliable public transportation
widespread respect for art and social commentary (including protests against / critiques of the city's own flaws)
People waiting on a subway platform; while not apparent from the photo, the platform had many people who were waiting for infrequent train service.
Garbage piled on the street for collection; NYC does a good job with trash removal, but not having dumpsters/somewhere else to put garbage seems a little uncaring to me.

photo.title: Uncaring 3

description._content: Tags on a building and a watertower in Brooklyn. I struggled with this one: the tags show a certain disrespect to the city and its buildings yet the slogans on the water tower could be considered street art.

photo.tags: newyorkcity male art publicspace culture communication 28 uncaring

description._content: Litter on the subway
Chalkboard sign for a new "hipster" barber shop that opened next to my apartment building. A symbol of how the city is becoming more homogenous and unaffordable.
Holiday decorations light up the street during the dark winter night.
Medical clinic advertising the various languages its staff speaks; I love living in a linguistically diverse place where peoples needs can be met in their preferred language.
Craft fair in an old warehouse; love the support for small businesses in a repurposed space.
Ad for help via text for expecting and new mothers from the city health department.

Train delay. The last few weeks have been a terrible few weeks for train delays, and this is a photo of just one of the recent delays I've encountered. On a couple recent nights, the train line I usually took wasn't running at all--and this was rush hour! Often times, we don't hear announcements about the delays until we've been waiting many minutes, and the announcements aren't always helpful or audible. There is a feeling among myself and others in my generation that our city, state, and federal government is not investing in modernizing public transportation, which many of us rely upon. Signals in the MTA are out of date and create unnecessary delays. A sick passenger can tie up the train lines for a whole rush hour. It seems like other world cities do not have nearly this level of frustration b/c they have invested in modern public transportation arteries. But in New York State and at the federal level, public officials seem unwilling to invest serious money in urban public transit.

no heat. This photo touches on similar issues as photo number 1. There was no heat in my building for nearly a week and sporadic hot water. The building was very noncommunicative until tenants including myself persisted in calling the, so then my super put up this sign that was not terribly helpful.

Kate and William. This is kind of a funny one. I saw this photo and the headline "Kate and William try to seem normal" and couldn't believe it. Obviously there's nothing normal about an image of a prince and duchess about to attend a lavish fundraiser wearing expensive clothing. NYC has incredible levels of income inequality, and the displays of wealth here dwarf even the royal couple. Of course, this is the result of larger social and economic forces, but NYC can definitely feel like a place that is built for the super rich at the expense of everyone else.

Apartment hall. This is a photo of an old converter box that was just left in front of my doorway in my apartment building. Someone must have been moving out recently, and they had left various things in the hall of the building. My building manager and super are not good about maintaining the building (there is also garbage left in the halls sometimes and the floors are old and cracked, even though they could be restored nicely), so in some cases I just have to throw things away. The reason I see this as a city problem is because enforcement and oversight of buildings in NYC I've found is shoddy so that landlords can get away with so much. Many of them, including mine, are trying to push out tenants who have lived in the building for awhile so they can get new, higher rent paying tenants and eventually develop the building so it becomes market rate and people are paying upwards of $3200 for a 2 bedroom, etc.

Prospect Park ice rink. I live a few blocks from Brooklyn's jewel, Prospect Park. It is a wonderful place, and this past year, they erected a skating rink (roller skating in summer/spring and ice skating in the winter). I happened past the rink on a run one recent weekend day, and it was packed with people. One thing I love about NYC is how much people take advantage of public spaces like this one, so when the city and private companies invest in these spaces, it really makes New York feel happier and more liveable.

Park Slope Food Coop 2 & 3 are photos of the Park Slope Food Coop's newspaper, which welcomed me and many others as new members. I joined the food coop to get high quality food for low prices and also heard it was a nice--if sometimes lively--community of people. I have not regretted joining. In NYC groceries, esp. at nicer grocery stores, are very expensive, and in the Food Coop it's extremely affordable. There is also a sense of community when you shop there, which one cannot say about going into a Whole Foods or a Westside Market or Fairway, where there are some sharp elbows.

Park Slope Food Coop 2 & 3 are photos of the Park Slope Food Coop's newspaper, which welcomed me and many others as new members. I joined the food coop to get high quality food for low prices and also heard it was a nice--if sometimes lively--community of people. I have not regretted joining. In NYC groceries, esp. at nicer grocery stores, are very expensive, and in the Food Coop it's extremely affordable. There is also a sense of community when you shop there, which one cannot say about going into a Whole Foods or a Westside Market or Fairway, where there are some sharp elbows.

Karaoke. This is just a photo of a recent night with a bunch of friends at a longtime bar called the Old Carriage Inn, that has karaoke. This bar has been around forever, and the bartenders are friendly and the place just feels unpretentious and fun. A lot of old school bars have had to shut down in recent years b/c of rises in rents and have been replaced by places that feel less personal. So it is great to have this place around.

Holiday decoration. There were better photos I could have taken of the holiday decorations around my neighborhood in Brooklyn, but one thing I love about NYC is that the creativity of residents shines through during the holiday seasons, especially Halloween & Christmas/Hannukah. Park Slope and Grand Army Plaza also have put up some lovely decorations that make the neighborhood feel a lot warmer, especially during a period of the year when days are getting shorter & people are stressed out.
Dog. I saw this dog outside of the Park Slope YMCA the other night. New York is a great city for pets in many ways, and while I don't have any myself, it is great to see so many on the streets.
An MTA subway poster communicating who not to associate with. The MTA always has bizarre ways to try and communicate right from wrong and they never address the root causes in their messages..
A vacant lot that may or may not be developed soon. The garbage tells me it's been sitting like that for a while...
An empty subway car is a pretty desolate place. Especially when there is a lone homeless man sitting on one end and no one dares to get in...
The carcass of a forgotten bike...

KFC, a place where if you're not drunk and out at 4am you don't eat. The food is horrible for you and this particular location tends to leave their trash strewn all over the sidewalk next to the loading dock...
Vans in a lot that look like Dooms day is close. It seems they are about to depart soon in a convoy...
The subway filled with people is always a place that you can share something very human, travel.
A random film crew walking down my block. A group of friends that are caring of each other and my neighborhood.
An Architecture review at Pratt where I was invited to sit as a critic. A safe place where I always feel like I can express myself entirely.
The man that makes my coffee, I speak spanglish with him every morning- an excellent way to start the day!
The man that makes my coffee, I speak spanglish with him every morning- an excellent way to start the day!
Bodega next to my apartment where I get my coffee every morning in Bushwick, Brooklyn.
A bike shelter in Union Square. It's interesting to see the city care about keeping the rain off of bicycles.

I took this photo actually only because i sometimes hate the weather here but thats too general .Like every other large city berlin is not free of uncaring corners. The city has its flaws. We have homeless people and criminality here. But these things do not stand out. Most of the people are content of living here.

Im sorry for this picture. ^^ I just took a photo of the first thing that came into my mind when i thought about uncaring parts of berlin. I think everyone in berlin knows the joy of stepping in a pile of dog shit.
Currently there are really beautiful christmas markets around in berlin, with delicious food and sweets.
This photo is taken at a bar we often go to. Berlin has many really good bars, cafes and places to hang out at
This is a small shop near where i live. I took this photo because i never saw it closed, regardless of time or day of the week. In Berlin you can find many more of these.
You can reach your destination here always easily via public transportation. There are many bus and train stations here and you will find your way even at night.
Berlin is famous for its kebab shops. You can't find a dner as good in Berlin in any other City.
